passages.text: A (perceived) value trap the neednt be - potential path forward

Following the last few months of tumultuous headline performance, Wendy's U.S. business is at a critical juncture with several potential changes to the company's strategy being an opportunity. The main goal of this piece is to dive into the company's capital allocation strategy and revisit the capital structure to improve the investability of the equity story. We focus on 1) capital allocation going forward - specifically focusing on development, remodels, and return to shareholders, 2) capital structure - right net leverage for the current business, and 3) easy- to- address product and marketing opportunities.

The current CFO/internim CEO, Ken Cook, is the "probable" permanent CEO, which presents opportunity for a faster strategy overhaul versus following Kirk Tanner's March 6 outlook. As a reminder, we look forward to hosting interim CEO/ CFO Ken Cook and CAO Suzie Thuerk for investor meetings in NYC on Sep 18.

We incorporate a new alternative capital allocation plan and capital structure strategy (detailed below) that should improve medium- to long- term store economics/franchise profitability. Valuing Wendy's at \(6.25\%\) F28E FCF yield or \(\sim 150\) bps discount to large- cap (MCD, YUM, QSR, and DPZ) valuations for new \(\) 14\(Dec 2026 price target. Total capex (including build- to- suit but excluding principal payments on capital leases) slows from\) \sim \$170\mathrm{in} F25–27\mathrm{to}\sim \$150\mathrm{in} F28\mathrm{but now with remodel capex contributing to} >75\% \(of total\) \sim \$490\mathrm{m} \(spend modeled between\) F26–28\(. This is below the company's\) \sim \$550\mathrm{m} \((see Table 4) implied\) F26–28\(outlook based on the similar levels of build- to- suit/franchise funding at\) \sim \$70\mathrm{m}

Total net debt/leverage falls from \(\) 3.02b/5.8x\(existing F25 to\) \ \(2.62b / \sim 4.5x\) in F28 (vs \(\) 2.86b / \sim 5x\(pvs), while a total of\) \sim \$515\mathrm{m} \(is returned to shareholders (dividends and repurchases) through this period. This is after repaying\) \sim \$400\mathrm{m} \(of debt from\) \sim \$350\mathrm{m} \(proceeds following a modeled sale- leaseback of 155 company owned land/buildings within the 400 - co store base in 4Q26. FCF calculated after backing out principal payments on capital leases is modeled to - grow from\) \sim \$120\mathrm{m} \(in F25 to\) \sim \$175\mathrm{m} \(in F28 with much of the growth coming from U.S. AUV expansion, rather than new development. See Tables 1- 3 for full model details.

As part of the capital reallocation plan, we argue for no new U.S. development through F28. Specifically, we recommend pulling away from the funded franchise development. We believe novel financial structures do not change the fact that new unit returns - mostly due to a \(\) 2.0m\(AUV box - are increasingly non - competitive vs other faster growing fast casual and traditional QSR chains (see Tables 6 - 7). This is essential and should be top of mind for Wendy's management as even an RBI style franchisor support is likely needed at this point - in the context of declining franchise store profits in F25 - as the Wendy's U.S. system likely slips to\) \#3\$ QSR burger chain below
Sources for: Style Exposure - J.P. Morgan Global Markets Strategy; all other tables are company data and J.P. Morgan estimates.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

Remain Overweight. Following the last few months of tumultuous headline performance, Wendy's U.S. business is at a critical juncture with several potential changes to the company's strategy being an opportunity. Our thinking then - and still - is based on a value- oriented opportunity with focus on 1) capital allocation going forward - specifically focusing on development, remodels, and return to shareholders, 2) capital structure - right net leverage for the current business, and 3) easy- to- address product and marketing opportunities.

Raising Dec 2026 price target to \(\) 14\(. We incorporate a new alternative capital allocation plan and capital structure strategy that should improve medium - to long - term store economics/ franchise profitability. Valuing Wendy's at 6.25% F28E FCF yield or - 150bps discount to large - cap (MCD, YUM, QSR, and DPZ) valuations for a new\) \ \(14\) Dec 2026 price target.

Market8%Sector3%Macro8%Style14%Idiosync.67%Factors6M Corr1Y CorrMarket: MSCI US0.250.28Sect: Cons Discretionary-0.28-0.22Ind: Consumer Serv0.080.20Macro:Economic Surprise-0.34-0.24Non-Energy Commodity-0.23-0.19US 10yr yield-0.16-0.17Quant Styles:LowVol0.460.38DivYld0.470.37Momentum-0.48-0.36

- We now model F26-28 global store development at a 1.3% CAGR vs 3-4% discussed in Mar'25, comprised entirely of ex-US growth. Following reallocation of capital from new US and funded franchise development to remodels, we model sharper headline comps/AUV recovery for the U.S. business with 20-25% of U.S. store base remodeled each year driving a conservative 5% AUV lift to drive overall SSS by 100-150bps. Versus a normalized +1.5-2% comp trends, we model +3% U.S. comps in F27/28. F26 will be a transitory year where current negative comp trends are modeled to inflect positive from 2Q26+ with the full year remaining at 0-1%. Our new F28 EBITDA is \(\sim\) \$572m (after \(\sim\) \$25m lost from sale-leaseback above) vs a comparable \(\sim\) \$557m previous, and EPS moves to \$1.10 vs \$1.05 previous.

- Wendy's hopes to provide an exceptional guest experience - we believe this starts with more robust store fronts and an elevated in-store experience and atmosphere. Better in-store design/functioning, lighting, fresh signage/brighter decors, and even a tap-to-pay POS should improve customer experience. The last "Image Activation" cycle began in 2011 and is said to be 92% complete exiting 2024. Another, presumably smaller spend "2.0" is an ongoing necessity to keep the asset base current. Goal of the proposed plan is to have at least \(\sim 80\%\) of the U.S. store base fully current by 2028.

- A 10-year remodel cycle is mandatory for any brand, and a full remodel (no scrape/rebuild) likely costs upward of \(\sim\) \$500k. Our capex plans assumes a smaller (\(\sim\) \$200k per U.S. system store) and quicker (three-year) "remodel 2.0" cycle to largely address the above shortfalls in addition to the already planned technology/digital upgrades (\(\sim\) \$50k per store). About \(\sim 15\%\) of the company system is remodeled each year, but more importantly Wendy's should contribute \(\sim\) \$250m from F26-28 to fund 1) \(\sim 50\%\) of the remodel cost for the \(\sim 1,650\) franchise stores (see below) on company owned/leased properties, and 2) ideally \(\sim 25\%\) of remodel cost for the roughly two-thirds of the remaining \(\sim 3,000\) U.S. franchise stores that are underperforming and/or face capital constraints at current store economics.

- Wendy's has long reported D&A significantly \(>\) capex, often by 1.5-2.0x, with much of the variance resulting from lack of company contribution to the remodels for these \(\sim 1,650\) properties, from which Wendy's collects rents. In addition to ownership of 782 properties across the system (\(\sim 820\) including TimWen JV) including land/buildings or both with 490 of these leased to franchises, Wendy's sub-leases 1,156 properties to its franchises. The lack of remodel capex contribution is atypical to McDonald's and Tim Hortons, which co-invest in remodels alongside franchisees for remodels after contributing to store builds. Over time, we expect D&A and capex to converge upon following this practice, and our model now reflects this in F28.

- As part of the March 2025 capital allocation update, Wendy's planned to spend \$450-500m in total new development capex during F25-28, including funded build-to-suit franchise development. About 50-70 are company owned/operated stores (predominantly U.S.) and 200-250 are franchise stores with Wendy's funding land/buildings-on the company's balance sheet between F25-28. About \(\sim\) \$150-200m of capex is likely/already committed through 2026, but we believe the majority of the remaining \(\sim\) \$300-350m should be re-deployed toward store remodels, thereby not needing any additional financing to complete this remodel 2.0 cycle.

Wendy's net leverage exiting 2Q25 is at \(5.5x\) moving to 5.8x exiting F25, including \(\) 593m\(of capital leases. The company's definition excludes capital leases and translates to 4.6x exiting F25 vs the previous long - term goal of 3.5 - 5.0x. We believe a more appropriate goal for the current business should be 3.0 - 3.5x (or 4.0 - 4.5x including capital leases) based on muted EBITDA growth outlook/trajectory for F26+. This is matched with the fact that Wendy's remodel capex intensity has a long catch - up contribution period - across at least - 1,650 properties mentioned above. This would warrant for at least - \(\) 300m\(in net debt reduction by F28.

Global real estate development segment that includes franchise/other rents contributes \(\sim 20\%\) or \(\) 110 - 120m\(of Wendy's\) \ \(500 - 550m\) EBITDA. These franchise royalties and rents in addition to all company - owned assets are collateralized for the upcoming - \(\) 400m\(WBS financing facility, which could result in 150 - 200bps lower rate vs traditional debt offering. Focusing on the 155 company owned stores with owned land and buildings, monetizing these assets through sale leasebacks can yield -\) 300 - 350m of liquidity based on recent comps (Meritage Hospitality group data, REITs/landlord updates). Total real estate value of all the owned assets/properties could range between\) \ \(1.0 - 1.5b\)

A sale/leaseback comes in exchange for \(\) 20 - 25m\(of store profits/EBITDA (worth\) \sim 9x\(at\) \sim \$ 180 - 200m\(today per current EV multiple) with incremental rents paid by company to new landlord - and could also result in lower future remodel contributions to these properties. While it sounds as if little if any of these proceeds could (or should) be used for equity distributions, proceeds can be used to significantly downsize the WBS facility and bring leverage to 4.5x (including capital leases) levels discussed above. Upcoming fixed - rate debt maturities include -\) \ \(430m\) maturing in 2028, - \(\) 900m\(in 2029, -\) \ \(625m\) in 2031, and - \(\) 385m\(in 2032 - all these notes ranging between 2.3 - 4.6\%\)

International has been a \(25+\) year endeavor for the Wendy's business - with various fits and starts - and it is hard to see the company break through from here, especially given the inability to sustain years of material losses needed to develop scale in major markets. The 440- store Canada business is more homogenous to US business and currently with better headline trends. RoW is still unproven and cannot be credited for scale at this point. Focus should be to achieve profitability in even a few select markets at the earliest while competing as a #3 burger/chicken chain with MCD, BK, and KFC having far superior and well- penetrated presence. This is where being part of a larger public (or even private ecosystem) could benefit Wendy's with a more established franchise and supply chain networks to assist with profitable expansion outside the US.

Wendy's has largely held share in the QSR burger category since 2019 despite underinvesting and under- innovating in the business. See Table 6 for the top 20 burger chains in the country since 2019 - Wendy's has kept pace with the sales/units/AUV CAGR. Underinvestment in both capex (remodels) and opex (operations) across existing stores partly contributed to declining foot traffic in our view, especially when it mattered in a macro with a weaker low- income cohort and generally a more choiceful consumer. Sub- \(\) 75k\(income cohorts account for >50\%\) of Wendy's US system sales, and the brand competes directly with not only McDonalds, Burger King, and Taco Bell but also well capitalized private brands like CFA, In- and- Out, Raising Cane, and most importantly grocery, where over 80% of meals consumed originate from.

- Overwhelming store operations (and changes) matched with cluttered promotion messaging largely drove US comps/traffic underperformance of \(\sim 250 - 300\) bps vs Blackbox QSR in 1H25. 2H25 outlook doesn't imply any notable convergence (yet) as many QSR brands are competing (especially against c-stores and groceries) to regain their consistent value proposition and re-attract lost customers, while improving frequency of existing customers. We love Kevin Hochman's (Brinker) quote, "Marketing gets customer in, operations bring them back." Basic operational improvements such as ensuring kiosks and freestyle coke machines are fully functioning throughout the day improves execution consistency and drives higher guest satisfaction.

- A simple and clear menu/product calendar should be established going into 2026 – by consolidating all the value across \(5 - 7 - 9\) or \(4 - 6 - 8\) Biggie Bags, running easily executable LTOs (and collabs) maybe \(\sim 1x\) a quarter, and carefully phased menu innovation. Quality needn't be compromised to achieve this, and extensive product/day part discounting can be phased out if sufficient (re)investments discussed above are made. Investing in supply chain and operations for the long term should pay dividends immediately in the form of profitable store transactions. We are encouraged to see some early indications of product upgrades (like potato rolls vs regular buns) and various other tests – these should continue to be part of the core product overhaul strategy.
